title: Here’s who will be on the ballot for November’s 2025 City Council election
author: Sana Muneer
bullets: Eight candidates will advance in Boston's at-large city councilor race for the November 4 election, including four incumbents.
Districts 3, 6, 8, and 9 councilors are running unopposed and were not included in the preliminary election.
Mavrick Afonso leads in the closely contested District 7 race, with Samuel Hurtado securing a ballot spot as well.

title: Mayoral preliminary: Wu maintains huge lead over Kraft as both advance to November election
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Boston Mayor Michelle Wu leads by over 45 percentage points against Josh Kraft in preliminary election results.
Wu and Kraft advance to the November general election after the Tuesday preliminary vote in Boston.
Voter turnout reached nearly 18 percent, with over 75,000 ballots cast according to the Boston Elections Department.

title: What to know about the viral surrogacy lawsuit
author: Audrey Cooney
bullets: Cindy Bi sued surrogate Rebecca Smith after a miscarriage, claiming negligence and intentionally killing the fetus.
Smith moved and changed jobs due to harassment from Bi, who criticized her on social media and involved her family.
The surrogacy industry is expected to grow, but regulations lag, increasing risks for surrogates like Smith.

title: A healthy Hampus Lindholm could change Bruins’ fortunes in several areas
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Hampus Lindholm returns to Bruins training camp with a clean bill of health after missing 65 games last season.
Lindholm aims to improve Boston's power play, which ranked 29th in the NHL with a 15.2% success rate last year.
Lindholm's past performance with Pastrnak shows promise, with the duo outscoring teams significantly during power plays.

title: Drake Maye receives a ringing endorsement from Bills QB Josh Allen
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Josh Allen praised Patriots QB Drake Maye, calling him an 'unbelievable kid' with great skills on a podcast.
Allen and Maye developed a good relationship over the past year, facing off in Weeks 5 and 15 this season.
Drake Maye was the No. 3 pick in the 2024 NFL Draft and completed 30-of-46 passes in the season opener.

title: MBTA debuts train design to honor historic New England railroad, with more on the way
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: MBTA debuts refurbished commuter train honoring Boston and Maine Railroad with vintage maroon and yellow design.
Two additional commemorative trains for New Haven and New York Central Railroads to debut by year-end.
Refurbished trains include upgrades like remote monitoring and modern brake systems after overhaul started in 2019.

title: Patriots could be facing off against their former 1st-round pick in Miami
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Former Patriots guard Cole Strange is joining the Miami Dolphins from the Browns' practice squad.
Strange was drafted by the Patriots in 2022 and started 29 games before injuries affected his tenure.
The Dolphins need offensive line reinforcements after losing starting guard James Daniels to injury.

title: Tufts to go tuition-free for families making less than $150K
author: Sana Muneer
bullets: Tufts University will offer free tuition for U.S. families earning less than $150,000 annually starting next fall.
Families earning under $60,000 will receive a financial aid package with no student loans at Tufts.
The policy is funded by donor contributions and aims to increase diversity and reduce financial barriers.

title: Aunt now caring for young daughter of parents killed in Watertown murder-suicide
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: David Minasvand, 31, killed Nadia Abrahamian, 80, and Karine Asatryan, 35, in a Watertown home.
The couple's 1-year-old daughter, Madeline, will be cared for by her aunt Meline Asatryan.
A fundraiser for Madeline's care and future has raised over $37,000 from the community.

title: What Don Sweeney said about the Bruins’ playoff odds, timeline for new captain
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Don Sweeney expressed optimism about the Bruins' potential competitiveness for the 2025-26 season despite last year's setbacks.
Sweeney highlighted the importance of the Bruins' younger players stepping up to seize available roles in the upcoming season.
The Bruins will begin the season without a designated captain, allowing leadership to develop organically among the team.
